"Due to the inactive lifestyle and stressful life, many people get lifestyle diseases such as diabetes, high blood pressure, etc. Fit India Movement can encourage people to consume healthy food and maintain physical and mental fitness."

"With high-quality advertising and marketing practices, junk food manufacturers manipulate children to buy their food. This Fit India movement will make children think about the negative consequences of junk food. As a result, this movement will encourage children to consume healthy food."

"Some parents have put too much stress on their children to study. They send their children to school after school or simply let them sit down to do their homework, forgetting the importance of leisure time. This movement has the potential to change their minds, and as a result they can encourage their children to take off and play."

"This movement has the potential to make more people embrace traditional Indian martial arts such as Kathi Samu, Musti Yudha, etc., traditional dance forms and also healthy Indian snacks. And as a by-product, this can lead to job creation."
"The motivation to maintain fitness should start from childhood. But in India, many schools lack playgrounds. Lack of playgrounds can lead children to turn to inactive lifestyles."

"The Fit India movement must not reach people below the poverty line. In order to maintain a healthy lifestyle, both physical activity and nutritious food are necessary. But in India, many people are still undernourished and some people do not have access to clean drinking water. So, without solving the problem of poverty and lack of access to affordable nutritious food, some of the people in India will not be able to take advantage of this movement."

"Some people already focus on fitness. We can see this with the increasing number of fitness start-ups. But that's a small part of the people. In general, many people want to maintain an active lifestyle, but all they need is some encouragement. Thus, this movement repeatedly reminds us of fitness goals, as Swachh Bharat reminds us of how important it is to keep our environment clean."

"Since the invention of machines, the value of workers has been declining. They are used to support the machines. As a result, the work revolves around machines and not people. Workers are forced to work continuously with the machine."

"People are now dealing with trolling and cyberbullying. Hiding behind devices is to give them the courage to harass other people, which they may not do face to face. This is the deterioration of moral values."

"Some companies are developing strategies to use their apps for longer periods of time to keep us hooked on their apps and devices so they can show us ads. And they too can use our data to manipulate our decisions for their benefit. These strategies make people just goals."

"Industrialization increased working hours. Workers faced inhumane conditions. People cannot work and focus continuously like machines. Fast forward to today, we have technological devices to check how many hours we actually work. Some companies want to be connected 24 hours a day by emails and messages. This makes people feel less human."

"Our decision-making skills are also affected, as we are now asking search engines to know what is best. We are dependent on the knowledge base of the Internet even in offices to finish the work at hand. This concerns cognitive abilities (thinking, reading, learning, remembering and reasoning), which is an essential quality of the human being."

"Many face-to-face communications are also being replaced by virtual interactions. Many people now live in virtual homes, that's the smartphone. As the need to talk to each other decreases, the ability to communicate with each other decreases, which is a fundamental quality of beings."

"We are increasingly dependent on technological devices to guide us. For example, we keep reminders on smartphones and google the questions for answers. We outsourcing the activities that require intelligence to technology. Thinking, remembering and analyzing are essential characteristics of human beings. Too much dependence on technology makes us less human."

"With the help of technologies, people maintain and improve relationships with their friends, family and relatives. Many people also connect with each other to help those in need and to inspire each other. So now we have better tools to build human connections."

"Technology allows us to work from home. This facility helps employers to better understand their employees. Many companies are now adding elements to the work culture with the help of technology to make employees feel important."

"This bill gave the National Investigation Agency (NIA) exclusive powers. NIA may detain any person under UAPA without the prior approval of the state government. This is against the federalism guaranteed by the Constitution of India."

"The labelling of organisations as terrorist organisations and the labelling of individuals as terrorists are quite different. When a person is called a terrorist, he or she will be confronted with social exclusion and without a basis for existence, even if he or she has proved the opposite. The consequences will be irreversible. For example, in 2016 alone, 67% of the cases were acquitted, which means that they are probably innocent."

"If someone is booked under UAPA, the burden of proving their innocence is on them. This new amendment allows the government to seize its property. How will they pay for legal expenses to prove their innocence if they are falsely accused?"

"This will provide the central government with more police forces. The designation of individuals as terrorists can be abused. For example, several civil activists have recently been called urban naxals. If someone opposes the government, they will be vulnerable to being framed as terrorists. Because this change made it easier to call someone a terrorist."

"There is a growing threat of lone wolf terrorism. Lone Wolf Terrorists have no connection with terrorist organizations, but they carry out terrorist attacks alone. This new amendment to the UAPA has the potential to curb single-minded terrorism."

"In order to prevent the violation of human rights, a four-stage examination is added. The naming of individuals as terrorists is not being started by India. The USA, the European Union and China also have this provision."

"So far, only organizations have been designated as terrorist organizations, but not as individuals. The loophole is the individuals of the banned organizations that form new organizations and carry out terrorist activities. This proposed amendment to the Law on Unlawful Activities (Prevention) allows the government to designate individuals as terrorists, thus preventing terrorist attacks."
In view of the increasing threat from terrorists, terrorism must be combated vigorously. Therefore, a strengthening of the UAPA is necessary.

"At present, India does not have a well-developed infrastructure to ensure data security. On the other hand, industrialised countries already have an efficient infrastructure. So if we rush towards data localization, it may not be a wise move. Without an efficient infrastructure, data is vulnerable to cyber attacks. And the risk here is great, because it is financial data. But as the laws are made, it is a big challenge to develop efficient infrastructure at a faster pace."

"The storage of data in India means higher operating costs for payment system operators. Because in other countries they have cheaper alternatives. And even in cross-border transactions, they have to store the data in two places, which increases costs. It is likely that these additional costs will be passed on to consumers."

"Data localization laws lead to the establishment of several data centers on site. This will create many jobs and help the country's economy enormously. It will also drive innovation in this area, leading to cost-effective solutions."

"In the investigation of criminal offences, it will be necessary to access the payment data. If the data is stored abroad, it is very difficult to take the permission from that country for access to the data. This leads to delays in solving crimes. If the data is stored here in our country, this problem will be avoided."

India is a large consumer market for many foreign companies. India and other developing countries recognize the economic value of data and the importance of data localization. Data localization will benefit domestic companies and the country's economy. And we can also guarantee the security of the data.

"The data are seen as a 'new form of wealth'". In general, companies use data to understand consumers' needs and influence their behaviour. New products can be developed by analyzing the data to meet the needs of consumers. So the data has an economic value. In general, industrialised countries take advantage of this opportunity with their well-developed infrastructure. "

"We are in a globalized world. Currently, the world is running on the free flow of people, goods, services and data. Data localization laws seem to be part of protectionist politics, which poses a threat to the free flow of data."

"The US is against data localization laws. At the recent G20 summit, US President Donald Trump spoke out against data localization. Its stance is natural because it increases the operating costs of US companies. The bilateral relations between India and the US are important for both countries because we are involved in the export and import of IT services, professionals and goods etc. are intertwined. So imposing data localization laws without threatening Indo-US relations is another challenge."
"We can ensure data protection by locating the data."
Data localization can lead to state surveillance of their citizens.
"Data localization is important for data sovereignty, which means that citizens' data should belong to their governments and not to other countries."

"The law is very clear that RTI is not only concerned with government agencies alone. It is also intended for non-governmental organisations, which are mainly financed and controlled by the government. There are numerous subsidies (including tax exemptions) enjoyed by political parties, which essentially fund them by the government."
"Political parties are independent bodies, they do not have to be accountable to the public. They were not created by the Constitution or an act of Parliament."

"According to the RTI law, these organisations, wherever there is a public interest, must be transparent and subject to the law. There are now a number of private organizations, whether partially funded or fully; schools, hospitals, etc. which are subject to the RTI law and not just governmental organisations."
"There are adequate provisions in the Income Tax Act and with the Election Commission so that people can have all the information they want."

"The RTI Act contains provisions in Section 8 which mention the concept of the interest of competition. Certain exceptions are granted in cases where it can be demonstrated that the dissemination of information may harm the competitive advantage of the party. This is not only a problem with the political parties, but also with many governmental and private bodies."

"It is believed that political financing is the source of corruption. Citizens have the right to know where the political parties obtain these funds, how they spend them and on the basis of their decisions. Crony capitalism will be greatly hampered if political parties are brought under the RTI Act."

"According to the IT law, political parties do not have to disclose donations received under INR 20,000. An informal study conducted in 2010 on 6 major political parties shows that they raised Rs 700 crore. 95% of the amount was increased by amounts below Rs 20,000. There is a great possibility that the political parties will use this loophole to their advantage."
"Political parties declare certain promises in their manifestos. After the election, citizens have the right to know why the promises made by the political parties have not been fulfilled."

"Political parties are central to the functioning of democracy. Political parties continue to form the government. Government policy is then governed by party ideology. This makes it essential for the political parties to fall under the RTI field."

"If political parties fall under the RTI, this will affect their smooth internal functioning. Rivals can use RTI to insult each other. Since the political parties are not directly connected to the public, an RTI would be invalid."

"India as a whole regards educational institutions as working machines, we expect to become unemployed and get out of work. We do not realise that we need to improve our skills in order to be worthy of employment. This is the reason why more than 80% of engineers are unable to work and the figures for non-engineers are even worse."

" Although we have established institutes at national level over the past 40 years, we have not invested to maintain their standards. High-quality education requires resources. Even India's top institutes lack infrastructure, laboratories, resources, etc. And even what is available is only for students to pass the exam and sit idle the rest of the time."
"Today, no problem has a single solution and no new technology is related to a single discipline. We need multiple contributions from multiple disciplines, and our institutes have not done so."

"Indian students perform brilliantly when they go to different countries in the field of research. It means we don't lack talent, we don't lack infrastructure and a healthy environment for our sharp minds."

"We have not paid our teachers at the level that their colleagues in other countries earn. The result is that people hesitate to consider the idea of teaching as a career. We have also failed to attract successful foreign faculties to our institutes."

"Achieving excellence in everything takes time. By graduating, students acquire so much knowledge in the relevant field. This makes it easier for employers to train these students for industrial requirements."
"Each skill can be learned and mastered, even if we don't have a degree in it. And programming is no exception."

"Even if someone has an IT degree, they have to learn so many things to get into the IT job, because there is a gap between industrial standards and the skills taught in engineering colleges. Moreover, since technology is constantly evolving, even if someone has prepared for industrial standards in his or her degree, they must constantly learn new technologies in order to remain relevant in the labour market. So since the learning curve will also be there for IT students, students from non-IT backgrounds can also learn these things and get into IT jobs."

"The number of IT jobs is growing rapidly due to the technological revolution. So there will be more jobs in the IT sector. And if the recruits are very strict about the degree, they may miss a large pool of talent who have a non-IT background."

"Now we have so many online course platforms through which we can learn almost every skill from experts. We can also get certificates if we pass the tests. So, as Tim Cook said, a four-year degree seems old and traditional.”

"In many of India's engineering universities, we can easily pass on the subjects even if we don't have much knowledge in these subjects. This is the reason why many companies are unable to find suitable talent, even though there are so many qualified graduates. The willingness to become an expert in this field is therefore more important than a degree."
"If a student from a non-IT background has decided to start a career in IT, the efforts they put into graduating will be in vain."

"Although the new programming languages replace the old ones, the basic concepts are the same for almost all programming languages. So whoever has a degree in coding has an advantage over the student from a non-IT background."

"People change careers even after working in an area for several years because our interests change. So if someone can do this while having so many personal responsibilities, it's much easier for young people to learn a new skill."
"Variable pay definitely increases employee productivity. High-performing people feel well compensated and rewarded for their efforts, while low-performing people also feel motivated to improve."

"In variable wage systems, employees feel satisfied and motivated with their work. They believe they are an active part of the organization, the organization recognizes them as part of their growth and appreciates their efforts."
"Variable pay helps to retain valuable employees. This helps to retain good talent for a long time and thus reduces expenses for hiring new talent. This ensures stability for the organization."

" It has been found that it is difficult to retain workers in lean times when they are on variable wage systems. Workers who receive commissions do well when business is good, but they do badly when business is bad. In times of slow business, even top sellers may have difficulty making enough sales to earn a decent living. If the market is slow and contract workers cannot earn enough, they can look for other employment opportunities. In lean times, fixed wages can be more effective in deterring workers from using other options."

"Variable pay can lead to unhealthy competition between employees. They become less willing to help each other. Team cooperation can have a negative impact. In the long run, relations between colleagues can become bitter. While the employees in fixed wage systems are able to maintain cordial relations in the office."

"Most sales jobs have a variable component. This could have a negative impact on the employee's attitude towards customers. They can irrationally force customers just to make profits for themselves. You might overestimate the price to customers just to make more profit. "We must cut all funding for NGOs and all migration organisations within the EU. Then we can talk about how we can help the people who are already here and how we can help real people in need."
"We must agree that people who do not respect our immigration rights will be detained in repatriation centres."

"The country of origin should be absolutely the most important criterion for deciding who we leave in our countries. 160 Frenchmen would still be alive if we put the welfare of our own people above the people whose countries the Americans have bombed to pieces."
" It's time to be honest! Europeans have the right to self-determination like any other country out there! This is our home and a home for all is a home for no one."

"Our continent Europe is indebted and does not have the means to take care of people who have never paid taxes and continue to flout our laws! We already have enough poor people in Europe and we need to take care of them!"

"I do not agree to deprive people of their right to asylum and their right to live in the EU because they have come illegally. Instead, I would suggest facilitating legal migration. In this way, there would be no need to migrate illegally and risk your life."
The division of the refugees is a long-discussed plan. In the end, however, no group agreed to these plans. Some countries do not like these people at all.
